abstracts.cdata!:
The Railway Concession Project intends
            to improve Cameroon's transport sector sustainability,
            through the private operation of the railway sector, thus
            eliminating the burden on public finance for provision of
            railway services. The project components consist of: 1)
            rehabilitation, and modernization of the rail
            infrastructure, to be implemented by CAMRAIL, comprising
            rehabilitation of tracks; construction of small, and medium
            structures, and bridges; acquisition of signaling, and
            radio-telecommunications equipment to improve railway
            operational safety; and general engineering works, including
            the extension of the railway system to the port of Douala.
            International aid will further contribute to financing this
            component, in order to complement concessionaire financing,
            particularly civil works, sleepers, and welding; 2)
            rehabilitation of rolling stock, track maintenance
            equipment, and workshops, for which CAMRAIL will have
            overall responsibility for implementing this component,
            given it will not be financed by the Bank; and, 3)
            environmental, and social activities, focused on the
            clean-up of polluted railway sites prior to concessioning,
            particularly the creosote facility, and the diesel fuel
            stations in Douala, and Yaounde, and includes engineering
            studies, and pollution abatement supervision works.
            Regarding social issues, overall safety measures, and
            resettlement compensation of populations in the railway
            right-of-way will be undertaken. In accordance with the
            Concession Agreement, the Government assumes responsibility
            for pollution abatement that predates the concession,
            whereas CAMRAIL will implement this activity on behalf of
            the Borrower.
